content.question:
NO CALCULATOR IS ALLOWED FOR THIS QUESTION.

Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit.

Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point.

Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for which <math alttext="f of x" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is a real number.

The figure above shows the graph of <math alttext="h prime" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>h</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>, the derivative of a twice-differentiable function <math alttext="h" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>h</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, on the closed interval <math alttext="negative 5 is less than or equal to x, is less than or equal to 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. The graph of <math alttext="h prime" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>h</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> has horizontal tangent lines at <math alttext="x equals negative 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="x equals negative 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, and <math alttext="x equals 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. The areas of the regions bounded by the <math alttext="x" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-axis and the graph of <math alttext="h prime" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>h</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> on the intervals <math alttext="open bracket, negative 5 comma negative 3, close bracket" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>[</mo><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>,</mo><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow></mrow><mo>]</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="open bracket, negative 3 comma 0, close bracket" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>[</mo><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow><mo>]</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="open bracket, 0 comma 2, close bracket" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>[</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>]</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, and <math alttext="open bracket, 2 comma 3, close bracket" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>[</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>]</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> are <math alttext="7" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>7</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="5" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>5</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="4" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, and <math alttext="3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, respectively. The function <math alttext="h" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>h</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is defined for all real numbers and satisfies <math alttext="h of 1 equals 12" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>h</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>12</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="h of 3 equals 11" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>h</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>11</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(a) Find the <math alttext="x" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-coordinate of each critical point of <math alttext="h" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>h</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> on the open interval <math alttext="negative 5 is less than x, is less than 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>5</mn><mo><</mo><mi>x</mi><mo><</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>.

frqParts.text:
NO CALCULATOR IS ALLOWED FOR THIS QUESTION.

Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit.

Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point.

Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for which <math alttext="f of x" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is a real number.

The figure above shows the graph of <math alttext="h prime" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>h</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>, the derivative of a twice-differentiable function <math alttext="h" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>h</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, on the closed interval <math alttext="negative 5 is less than or equal to x, is less than or equal to 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. The graph of <math alttext="h prime" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>h</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> has horizontal tangent lines at <math alttext="x equals negative 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="x equals negative 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, and <math alttext="x equals 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. The areas of the regions bounded by the <math alttext="x" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-axis and the graph of <math alttext="h prime" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>h</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> on the intervals <math alttext="open bracket, negative 5 comma negative 3, close bracket" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>[</mo><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>,</mo><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow></mrow><mo>]</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="open bracket, negative 3 comma 0, close bracket" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>[</mo><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow><mo>]</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="open bracket, 0 comma 2, close bracket" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>[</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>]</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, and <math alttext="open bracket, 2 comma 3, close bracket" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>[</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>]</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> are <math alttext="7" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>7</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="5" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>5</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="4" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, and <math alttext="3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, respectively. The function <math alttext="h" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>h</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is defined for all real numbers and satisfies <math alttext="h of 1 equals 12" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>h</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>12</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="h of 3 equals 11" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>h</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>11</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(a) Find the <math alttext="x" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-coordinate of each critical point of <math alttext="h" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>h</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> on the open interval <math alttext="negative 5 is less than x, is less than 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>5</mn><mo><</mo><mi>x</mi><mo><</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(b) Identify the critical point from part (a) which corresponds to a relative maximum of <math alttext="h" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>h</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. Give a reason for your answer.

(c) Find the value of <math alttext="h" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>h</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> at the <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-coordinate identified in part (b). Show the computations that lead to your answer.

(d) Find the absolute maximum value of <math alttext="h" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>h</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> on <math alttext="negative 5 less than or equal to x, less than or equal to 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. Justify your answer.
(e) On what open intervals is <math alttext="h" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>h</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> both increasing and concave down? Give a reason for your answer.

(f) Explain why there must be a value of <math alttext="b" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>b</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, for <math alttext="1 less than b, less than 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo><</mo><mi>b</mi><mo><</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, such that <math alttext="h of b equals 11.5" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>h</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>b</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>11.5</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(g) Find <math alttext="the limit as x approaches 3 from the left, of, the fraction with numerator h of x, minus 11, and denominator x squared, minus 9, end fraction" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><munder><mrow><mi>lim</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>→</mo><msup><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></munder><mfrac><mrow><mi>h</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>11</mn></mrow><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mo>−</mo><mn>9</mn></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. Give a reason for your answer.

(h) The function <math alttext="p" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is defined by <math alttext="p of x equals, open parenthesis, h of x, close parenthesis, squared" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>p</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><msup><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>h</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>. Find <math alttext="p prime of 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. Show the computations that lead to your answer.

topic.text: 1.16: Working with the Intermediate Value Theorem (IVT)

skill.text: Skill 1.D: Identify an appropriate mathematical rule or procedure based on the relationship between concepts (e.g., rate of change and accumulation) or processes (e.g., differentiation and its inverse process, anti-differentiation) to solve problems.
